 I didn't necessarily mind the format, although I think one could hardly call it a debate. When one looks over our history, the suggestion that a format of "one minute responses and 30 second rebuttals" and "raise your hand if you did..." constitutes a grueling and informative debate is quite laughable.
 
 I think in the upcoming election we should find an individual who really, really, really does NOT want to be President, and then force him (or her) to be President. I would also support this method of selection for all the Senators and Representatives in Congress as well.
 
 As for the questions: the ones I saw were mostly stupid. For example, there was a question asking the candidates to tell us who their favorite teacher was. Who cares, and how is that relevant anyway? And another example: "What are you going to do to standardize voting?" Well, considering that the Constitution places this squarely in the hands of the States, a President really cannot do anything about it. Yet another irrelevant (and actually, quite stupid) question.
 
 After hearing such ridiculous nonsense, its no wonder to me that we are in the mess we are in as a political system.

In another thread we spoke of having "rational debate". While I said it was not a requirement you clearly can see the result of such a debate as seen last night.

 Just because there is a debate, that doesn't make it a rational debate. :( 
 
 Political debates of this sort are rarely based fully on rational reasons but on political tactics and sound bites. Politicians have the unenviable task of trying to please everyone, or at least most of their constituency, so they cannot be as honest as they may like to be. Also, unfortunately, recently, people seem to be more swayed by sound bites than by fully expounded reasoning.
 
 Nevertheless, I continue to hope that the decisions of politicians behind the scenes once in office are based on more real discussion and reasoning than one sees in these "debates".
